response.answer_text: The most important thing I learned in school wasn’t any single topic or piece of information. What I learned was how to go about learning. It sounds simplistic, but if you have that kind of mindset, much of the rest will follow. I learned how to organize my thoughts around questions and topics. Instead of taking a question as literal and simplistic, I learned to think about the question in context: who was asking, why were they asking, and what did I think they actually wanted to know from an answer? Only then would I start researching and developing an answer. I learned to explore around the edges of questions and topics. What other topics might be related, and how? Such explorations have often led me to completely new topics to learn about. Going back to basics: read. Be voracious about knowledge. Before the Internet, I read newspapers 7 days a week. Now I browse multiple online sources daily, and read numerous articles. If a topic is interesting, I’ll save it, and follow up by doing additional searches and reading topical material in greater depth. If what you want to learn is related to a skill, then you must exercise that skill. The way to martial arts mastery is through practice - there is no substitute. If you want to learn about knife throwing, start practicing. Think about the topics you wish to learn. Search out sources, whether online, in books, via classes or on-the-job training, and find a way to immerse yourself. This has all be extremely general advice - but your question is also quite general. If you want to learn but don’t know where to begin, I suspect you’ll have to begin within, and try to figure out what it is you want to learn about. Once you’ve identified at least a starting point, you can pursue some of the suggestions above to expand on that initial topic.

Knowledge is not measured by what's stored in the head; it's your productivity, i.e. what you do and what don't do! 2) Write, write, and write, so as to garner people's attention to your   evolving acumen and  growing expertise, which often can lead to more  public speaking gigs and consulting engagements. 3) Begin with a  warm, sincere and genuine interest in people all around  you, as people  are your greatest resource, as well as your wonderful  opportunities to learn, grow and change. 4) Don't forget to attend selected conferences, seminars and workshops to keep yourself abreast of trends and developments in your as well as outside your industry, as everything in business - as well as in life - is connected in some ways;  Naturally, don't hesitate to seek as much opportunities as possible to rub shoulders with like-minded professionals inside as well as outside your industry, with the longer-term view to gain diverse - or even contrarian - perspectives; 5) Always listen intently, and talk less. 6) Keep  learning - and doing - new things, so as to gain expanded  perspectives  and new experiences.  Evolving experiences = applied  knowledge! 7) Develop a idea/insight generating mindset and a  problem solving  attitude, so that folks around you can turn to you for  advice and help. Nevertheless, here are a few good tips for enhancing your idea/insight generation: - be acutely observant of your environment, by using all your senses;- be curious and inquisitive;- be open-minded to new and even radical possibilities;- suspend judgement;- make unlikely connections;- ask questions, all kinds, especially open-ended ones, like "what if?", "why not?",  "So what?", "What now?", etc.- think like a child, but don't be childish, so to develop the beginner's mindset;- learn to see things backwards, inside out, and upside down; inside the box as well as outside the box, plus no box at all;-   learn to see from atop; see ahead; see beyond; see behind; see   sideways; see beneath; see behind; see from within; and see through, so   as to develop multi-directional and multi-development viewpoints;- hitchhike; copycat; piggyback;  leapfrog on other peoples' ideas, as "Ideas Build on Ideas";- you can make use of the simple but proven SCAMPER technique [it dates back to the 1950's], to expand your idea generation;-  likewise, you may want to explore the more elaborate but proven CPSI  methodology of the US-based Creative Education Foundation, to expand  your idea generation;- for the more adventurous, you can also take a  look at the Synectics group brainstorming process, which also dates back  to the 1950's; 8) Go all out to share your knowledge, experience and acumen, locally and globally, orally or in written form, as "Knowledge Shared is Power Squared". 9) Make globetrotting a part of your expansive lifestyle, as continual interactions with diverse knowledgeable as well as ordinary folks around the globe often expand and rejuvenate your mental horizons. 10) Last but not least, be humble. First, understand that “knowledge” is anything that is true—and nothing that isn’t true. More people than not believe many falsehoods to be true. This is so because many, influential and reputable sources are actively engaged in concealing important truths from as many people as will permit it. Don’t permit it. The former group are established, institutionalized, and they have conspired for generations to grow obscenely wealthy by filling the world with lies. Go in search of knowledge—but be warned. There is an unlimited number of wrong answers to every question. Not all popular theories are correct, and not all obscure or maligned theories are incorrect. To sort this out, you’re going to need three things: Judgment. “Educated” only means that you have gone through a process. “Formal education” means it was a process of someone else’s design that happened to acquire a good reputation. None of that guarantees that what you come away with was all that is known—or could be known. You don’t need to trust anyone if you know what they know; create your own belief set. Read, ponder, and re-read until you think you understand, then make your own decision—but always be flexible enough to update your information and your belief set.Character. If you don’t have the guts to stand up to people who are lying and/or are mindless followers, you don’t deserve any truth. Ridicule is part of the standard package of deceivers tactics, so be prepared to stand alone while fools laugh at you. Don’t believe or follow anyone because of who they are, what they own or what they seem to know. Neither do you want to identify yourself by what you know—you are what you do. A collection of knowledge may give you advantages, but someone else always knows more than you.A guy could be right about 99 things, but wrong about one. Be your own man or you’ll never know which one thing he is wrong about—and you’ll be wrong, too. A person of character won’t be susceptible to ad-hominem attacks—arguments that attack a person when his position is too strong to disprove logically. That means even the people you hate the most are probably right about something. Don’t get caught up in joining groups or labeling people who hold opposing views. Learn your own truth.Research. True answers can be found anywhere—but the best stuff is in the places that you’re told not to look. In fact, the more the machine ridicules any particular idea or source—that’s the more you should be curious about what the’re trying to hide. Truth can be concealed behind two things: 1) a lie 2) a person’s desire for ignorance.With the advent of the internet, many great documentaries have become available, and some of us learned many things that government-accredited institutions had decided we didn’t need to know. School is good for what it’s good for, but I learned more from YouTube than I ever learned in a classroom.True answers aren’t always easy, and easy answers aren’t usually true. Pay the price, do the work—or die a fool. Those are your choices.

1. Read the newspaper. This will allow you to be up-to-date with the latest information and form your own opinions about the articles written. Furthermore, nonfiction books could even be an opportunity for personal development and growth. 3. Watch documentaries or educational videos. I know, this sounds boring, but if you find the right thing to watch it might turn into the best hour you’ve spent watching TV! If you hate reading, this is an excellent alternative to getting your daily dose of knowledge while still relaxing in your couch! 4. Subscribe to feeds of interesting information. Truth is that we spend hours daily on our phones- specially social media. Why not fill it up with information that will help you grow? Get smarter every day by following pages that post “fun facts” or the news. 5. Work out. Read. Travel. Watch. Take classes. Talk to experts. Read selectively: Read non-fiction. There are tons of biographies written by authors of reliable standing. I recommend David McCullough and Erik Larson, but there’s many others who write the facts of a person’s life or events in history or science or any subject without including the deep-seated bias that some writers use. Travel: Tours are fine, but I never use them. Get out and meet the “natives”, the people who actually live there. Talk to them on the train, as you’re walking from one place to the other, on the subway, tube, or Metro. Don’t be intrusive but just chat. It’s interesting. I have taken tours but within the context of where I was. For example, when my daughter and I were at the Vatican, we signed up for a tour through it just to learn what it was we were observing. Same thing in Oxford, England. We signed up for a tour when we visited the Bodleian Library. Travel nearby: I live two hours from Washington, DC. I recently visited the capitol building. There’s the Supreme Court building. Smithsonian, National Gallery, etc. All very broadening. Map out places of interest within a two-hour radius of where you live, make a list then visit them. Documentaries: You can watch documentaries by the hour. Just make sure they are produced, etc by those who have integrity in presenting the facts. Take classes: Be selective of what classes you take. There are community colleges or four-year colleges who allow you to monitor a class. You don’t have to pay but you have the benefit of learning something from experts. Some years ago, an acquaintance of mine even went so far as to call the local high school and monitor a class on world history. She enjoyed it, but I’m not sure many schools would permit it. Talk to experts: No doubt there are many people you know who have careers about which you know little or nothing about. Sit down and listen to what they do. You may be surprised at what you’ll learn.

The way you improve your knowledge is by comparison. Learning a bunch of random facts or ideas is not going to improve your knowledge. I am making the assumption that what you want is to be wiser, to have more understanding. If I am mistaken in that and what you really want is to know more facts, all you need is an encyclopedia. Start with Volume 1 and read it enough times that you can recall the facts contained within that volume. Then move on to Volume 2. That’s how you become Jeopardy smart. You know a bunch or random facts and can remember them at will. That has nothing to do with knowledge. Well, maybe they are related a little bit; you need to understand the language the facts are communicated with. Other than that, random bits of information do not constitute knowledge. Improving true knowledge is about knowing ideas and facts and then assembling them into an understanding of how the world works. Then the memory of those facts helps you create meaning in your life and helps you understand the world and how other people think. When you understand like that, you have no prejudice and no misunderstanding of how life works and you can live your life understanding how you and your thoughts fit into the world. It’s not that learning a collection of facts is bad, it is a good thing. But it is only a good thing to begin with. True knowledge comes when you do not need to beat someone up with the things you remember and recite at will. True knowledge lets you understand the world. And that is pretty awesome. To increase true knowledge you need to do a few things, none of which are difficult, but all of which are necessary. First you need to realize you can’t possibly know and remember all the discrete pieces of information in the world. There are way too many for anyone to remember and way, way, way too many for anyone to make contextual sense of. Instead, it is OK to realize you don’t know everything, but are willing to lean about anything. That is most crucial idea for a scholar, that they are willing to learn new ideas. Once you accept that premise, the world will become open to you and your quest to make sense of the world. Second, you must be willing to let any piece of knowledge you encounter attach itself to any other piece of information you already know. For instance, if you were a fan of cooking competition TV shows, you know that once the competitors get their assignment for cooking , what they really do is race to get the best cooking utensils for themselves. Not only do they understand cooking, its chemistry and presentation facets, they know they have a much better chance of winning if they can use the best tools. The slower contestants who have not realized this yet, are left with the crappier utensils and almost always lose. They might be better chefs, but they lose the competitions because they cannot create the dishes in the best way possible with poor quality utensils. They already know they need not only f good ideas, but good presentation skills and the best pots and pans to win. They let those ideas hook themselves together without prejudice. Lastly, you need to be accepting of the idea that the way you have stitched your knowledge piece together might not be to your greatest understanding. And you must be willing to change. If you can’t you will be left with trying to defend your system of understanding against competing knowledge frameworks. So that instead of pursuing new knowledge to add to your compendium, you will spend all your energy defending your initial beliefs. And that does not lead to any increase in your knowledge whatsoever. Keep your senses open to learning new ideas and accepting new pieces of data into your understanding of the world. Work with those new thoughts until they fit into your increasingly relevant view of the world, then be willing to present your ideas into the world as a whole. This system works and will help you create the new understandings that all true knowledge seekers aspire to.

I take the term "general knowledge" to mean something like "knowing a little bit about a lot". It's the ability to know a lot of details, some plain trivia, some actually meaningful, about a lot of subjects, nothing deep, and no relationship to deductive reasoning.  Eons ago, when I was a wee lad, the main college-admittance test in my country had a section for quantitative reasoning, a section for language arts and deductive reasoning ("draw conclusions from the following article"), and a section for "general knowledge" where you'd get asked things like "which of the following composers was active during the Baroque period" or "what event triggered World War I". I think this part was removed from the test, on the grounds that it tests trivial knowledge rather than an ability to think creatively.  Anyway, you gain general knowledge by reading, lots, both fiction and non-fiction. Having a good memory helps, but I don't know that there's much you can do to improve that. Just read. Wander about in Wikipedia, listen to NPR, read things like The Great Philosophers or 1001 Inventions That Changed the World. Those are very, very shallow books, but they throw lots of details at you and help you grow that "general knowledge" part of your intellectual arsenal.  My personal bias is that this is something that's useful for a child or teenager to do. Young people are very good at absorbing such details, plus there's the added benefit of stumbling upon something that actually interests them and helping them discover their passion. I think as we get older it's more useful to start going deep, learning the actual ideas in areas that interest us and starting to make deductions, come up with original thoughts, create. Having "general knowledge" isn't any of those things, but it's a nice thing to pursue early on.

I will first point out that there are three stages to understanding, and knowledge is only the first. There is knowledge, then competency then wisdom. In terms of knowledge alone, there are types of knowledge. Two of the most important types are  Descriptive knowledge, which is what we usually think of as knowledge, and Procedural knowledge, which is what you need to hit a ball or play the piano. Intuition (Mind) is very close to procedural knowledge but it can be considered a different type of knowledge in its own right. That being said, I personally started off as a kid reading the encyclopedia. It was my favorite book. Then I read anything I could get my hands on: fiction, science, history, and so on. In this day and age, you can do the same thing with Wikipedia, although I was reading the Encyclopedia Britannica Junior, which was geared to eight to twelve year olds, which I was. This gives you a lot of declarative knowledge. But to go further, you need a guru or a teacher. This is because learning procedural knowledge has lots of frustrating dead ends, even for the naturally talented. Better to go through an apprenticeship with someone who has done it before. This is even true for the sciences as well as the arts. That is why there are labs and why graduate school is still a form of apprenticeship. You know you are getting somewhere when you can rely on your intuition. This means that your knowledge is so well integrated it comes naturally. I don't know of any royal road to that except for practice. But with practice you arrive at competence. As far as wisdom, well that is up to you. Some people never attain it. But wisdom is essentially competence transcended. It is competence with a deeper insight. For example, when I married my wife, she already had a nine year old daughter. I soon realized that she was a very gifted and wise parent. If I was puzzled about the way she did things, she could quote all of the texts and popular books on child rearing and why they suggested that they do things this way or that way. But she also knew when the book learning stops and she has to rely on her own hard-earned competence and intuition when the answers don't exactly apply. What she was doing is just the same as any artist or engineer. The book learning is the start, but true knowledge is when you transcend it.

The answer to developing knowledge is really quite simple, and perhaps memorable. To begin, three words are key to this quest. These words are information, knowledge, and application. It is first helpful to determine your preference to for jotting down brief notes. Let us call this our data storage device. If you are the type of person who uses your smart phone for everything, a free notes application is all you need. If you are the type of person who prefers to write with pen, then establish a special notebook, one that will be with you always so make it comfortable. When the moment occurs, and you will know it, jot down anything you hear, see, feel, or read that you find interesting, or appears to you as having some value. I am referring to “information” that you can do nothing with at this time. Do not try to remember this information. Some people develop clever memory techniques. Memory is not required in this plan to develop knowledge. Next, you will encounter “information” that you can immediately apply. As an example, let us say you are a new mother and just now heard an expert say breast-feeding is healthier for your baby than other types of milk according to scientific research. There is no need to jot this information in your data storage device, nor is there any need to try to remember this information. This “information” just became “knowledge” because there was application. If a mathematical equation existed to provide a sum answer for knowledge, it would look like: information plus application equals knowledge. Lastly, what happens to all of those brief notes in your data storage device? As an example, I was asked if I knew the capital of Arkansas. The answer was on the tip of my tongue, but I could not return an answer. I felt foolish because I put myself in a position as knowing the answer, however, I could not produce because at the time of learning the answer I did not have an application, so I did not have this knowledge. Alas! I have a data storage device and I was faithful to record the information. After having been asked the question, I promptly opened my storage device and in alphabet order I found the heading “Arkansas Capital” and replied, “Little Rock”! I then deleted this information from my data storage device, as this “information” just became “knowledge” because there was “application”.

The short answer is “read”. Without knowing what you want to know more about, I’m forced to present more generalized options. But learning is learning is learning, no matter what it is you want to learn. So, first of all, read. READ-READ-READ-READ-READ. Then read some more. Read everything. Even read stuff that you hate. Especially if you’re interested in devisive subjects such as politics or religion. The only way to find out what the other side is thinking about a subject like, “Are Republicans really as bad as they say?” or “Is it true that only current members of Westboro Baptist Church are going to heaven?” (I just made those up, BTW), is to read stuff you may not agree with. Sometimes, if a good, logical, compelling argument can be made, you may even change your mind. So, read everything you can get your hands on. If something looks interesting, read more. If it still looks interesting, find a website that features/teaches about/discusses the topic at more length. If you’re still intrigued, take an online class. If you still can’t get enough, enroll at some sort of institute of higher learning; whether that be a trade-school or Harvard Law. Obviously, Harvard Law may have more stringent enrollment requirements than ABC School of Diesel Mechanics down at the local strip-mall. But that’s beyond the scope of this comment. Once you’ve learned everything you can, you may want to make whateveritis a career. Good on ya! Give it all you’ve got. If not, find out everything you can about something else. Remember, learning doesn’t mysteriously stop when you hit your mid-twenties, or early thirties, or late sixties for that matter. Learning is a lifetime endeavour. Contributing and distributing the end-result of that knowledge (with appropriate compensation of course) is also a lifetime endeavor.

We all acquire knowledge in a similar way. We don’t have different learning styles, right/left brain advantages, photographic memories; nor speed reading advantages, or brain development inappropriateness. If you are eight years old you could be programming organs in RNA. You just need to master the prerequisites. [1] One of the most effective approaches to acquiring knowledge is teaching. This is how Richard Feynman acquired knowledge. He selected a concept then taught it to an imaginary person. He spoke, wrote, and drew the concept to his ‘student’. When he got stuck or felt that an explanation was too wordy, he went back to the reference material. He continued this process until he could recall everything using simple explanations and analogies. [2] The key is to acquire small chunks of knowledge and then apply them in different ways. Input, process, output. Teach, solve problems, or build something. Retrieving information from memory is the process of learning. When you use information in a new setting, that’s when you start understanding it. [3] To strengthen this process you can leverage five principles: Take breaksPlan and structure your learningHook your knowledge into multiple pieces of informationCreate a system for identifying knowledge blind spotsLeverage your emotionsBreaks enable you to remember knowledge longer. When you first acquire a piece of knowledge it expires in a few seconds/hours. To increase the expiry time, retrieve the knowledge just as you are on the point of forgetting it. This will prolong your memory. In the beginning take minute-long breaks, then increase the knowledge-specific breaks to hours, days and months. [3] Breaks also enable you to process a broader set of information. Focus narrows the activity to a small part of your brain. Some problems and concepts require that you use a broader set of information to understand them. This happens when you take breaks. [4] Structuring your learning improves retention, motivation, and clarity. Steve Wozniak did this. First he mapped out the prerequisites to build a proof of concept, the Apple 1. Then, for each new iteration of the Mac he could reuse that knowledge. This enabled him to deepen his knowledge. Since he had the trunk of the knowledge — the 80% that mattered — he could also attach the branches and the leaves. [5] When you structure your learning, add the same lenses: Frequency, value, and prerequisites. Which concepts will you need 80% of the time? What is the quickest way to add genuine value? How can I map out the prerequisites that are specific to my challenge? [6] Hook your knowledge into more information so that accessing it becomes easier. This refers back to a discovery in neuroscience: neurons wire together if they fire together. [7] To use this facet, study in various differing environments, use multiple senses, and apply your knowledge in various ways. If you need to recall knowledge for a specific occasion — say a presentation — do the opposite; study in an environment similar to the one where the knowledge will be used. This will make it more accessible in that type of environment, but less retrievable otherwise. Knowledge blind spots create failures. You run out of motivation and resources while learning things that you don’t need. They also decrease your knowledge acquisition. Your ability to acquire knowledge depends on your working memory, which becomes overloaded when you have significant gaps in your knowledge. This reduces your capacity to transfer knowledge to your long-term memory — your ability to acquire knowledge. [8] To avoid blind spots, take advantage of other’s learning journeys, have mentors, and gain feedback. This is not news for many. Still, we seldom notice our blind spots. That’s because we lack a prerequisite: Character. We are afraid of being vulnerable. [9] The final tactic for knowledge acquisition is controlling your emotions. What you find emotionally engaging is what you will think about, talk about, and work on. That’s the knowledge you will retain. Memory champions leverage this. They symbolize numbers in shocking mental images. Then they place the images in an imaginary house and create a story line. This skill allows them to remember long sequences of numbers. It’s a skill anyone can develop. [10] From a macro perspective, Steve Jobs took advantage of the same principle. He grew an emotional engagement to computers. He day-dreamed about them, talked about them, and worked on them. That’s how he acquired and grew his knowledge of them. Let’s sum it up: Acquire chunks of knowledge and apply them in different settings.Take breaks to improve your memory and your ability to solve problems.Structure your learning. Map out prerequisites, and start with concepts that you need 80% of the time. Prioritize knowledge that adds genuine, direct value.Learn in differing environments, work with knowledge in differing ways and use multiple senses.Read other’s learning journeys, have mentors, and gain feedback. Work on your ability to be vulnerable in order to do all of this effectively.Leverage your emotions by making information and problems more engaging. Generally by following these steps: Observation. (I see that something happens.)Inquiry. (I wonder why this happens.)Hypothesis. (I suppose because of this and that.)Data collection, facts. (Let's see if I can find more about it.)Establishing facts that corroborate each other. (Let's see if everything I have found so far lines up with my hypothesis.)Testing the hypothesis.
